title: The Fireflies of Joy
devotional:
Old Man Fitzwilliam sat on his porch swing, the rhythmic creak a counterpoint to the cicadas' drone. He watched his granddaughter, Lily, chase fireflies in the twilight. Her laughter, bright and unrestrained, was a stark contrast to the weariness that had settled in his bones. He hadn't felt joy like that in… well, he couldn't remember when. The garden, usually a source of immense pleasure, felt like a chore. His prize-winning roses seemed less vibrant, the tomatoes less flavorful. Even his old dog, Buster, who normally perked him up with a wagging tail, had failed to rouse him from his apathy. 

“Grandpa, look!” Lily exclaimed, holding up a jar filled with glowing insects. “I caught happiness!”

Fitzwilliam managed a weak smile. “Happiness isn’t something you catch, Lily-bug. It’s… something else.”

But as he watched her, the sheer delight on her face, he wondered if maybe she was onto something. Maybe joy wasn’t a grand, unattainable thing, but a collection of small, bright moments, like the fireflies flickering in her jar. He remembered Jesus’ words: “Very truly I tell you, unless you change and become like little children, you will never enter the kingdom of heaven” (Matthew 18:3). Perhaps childlike wonder was the key. Perhaps he had simply forgotten how to see the world with those eyes.

Over the next few days, Fitzwilliam made a conscious effort to rediscover joy in the small things. He took Buster for a walk in the woods, noticing the intricate patterns of sunlight filtering through the leaves. He sat in his garden, not to work, but to simply observe the hummingbirds flitting among the flowers. He listened to Lily’s stories with undivided attention, marveling at her imagination. And slowly, almost imperceptibly, the weariness began to lift. The colors seemed brighter, the flavors richer, the creak of the swing a more soothing melody. The joy he had thought lost forever began to glimmer, like a firefly in the twilight, reminding him that even in the midst of life’s challenges, God’s goodness is always present, waiting to be discovered.
image_description: A close-up of a glass jar sitting on a wooden porch railing, containing several softly glowing fireflies in a darkened, but lush garden setting at twilight
insights: The Gospel reminds us that true joy isn't dependent on external circumstances but is a fruit of the Spirit (Galatians 5:22). This joy is rooted in our relationship with Christ and sustained by His presence in our lives. Romans 15:13 says, “May the God of hope fill you with all joy and peace as you trust in him, so that you may overflow with hope by the power of the Holy Spirit.” This passage emphasizes that joy is not just a feeling, but a state of being that flows from faith and trust in God.
prayer: Heavenly Father, forgive me for allowing the burdens of life to dim the joy You have placed within me. Help me to rediscover the childlike wonder that opens my heart to Your blessings. Fill me with Your Spirit, that I may overflow with joy and peace, even in the midst of challenges. Remind me to look for the small, bright moments of Your presence in my life and to cherish them as gifts from Your loving hand. In Jesus’ name, Amen.
reflection: What activities or experiences once brought you great joy? How can you intentionally incorporate those things back into your life? What small, bright moments can you look for today? How can you cultivate a spirit of gratitude, even in the face of adversity?
